title: 105_hr1362
content: The Act titled "Veterans Medicare Reimbursement Demonstration Act of 1997" establishes a demonstration project. The Act establishes a demonstration project where the Secretary of Health and Human Services provides reimbursement to the Department of Veterans Affairs for healthcare services provided to targeted Medicare-eligible veterans. The project will run for three years starting from January 1, 1998, and certain Medicare requirements may be waived for its implementation. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may waive certain Medicare requirements for the demonstration project. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will designate up to three service areas for facility selection, favoring those suited to serve targeted Medicare-eligible individuals. The selection plan for the project favors facilities suited to serve targeted Medicare-eligible individuals based on demand, capability in billing, quality indicators, and other relevant factors. At least one facility near a closed military medical facility will be selected. The demonstration project selects facilities based on demand, billing capability, quality indicators, and other relevant factors. At least one facility near a closed military medical facility will be chosen. Participation is voluntary for targeted Medicare-eligible veterans, subject to capacity and funding limits. Cost-sharing requirements will be established for participating veterans. (c) Voluntary Participation.--Participation in the demonstration project is voluntary for targeted Medicare-eligible veterans, based on facility capacity and funding limits. Cost-sharing requirements will be the same as those for Medicare-eligible patients at non-governmental facilities. Payments received will be credited to the Department of Veterans Affairs medical appropriation. SEC. 3. DETERMINATION OF REIMBURSEMENT AMOUNTS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will reimburse the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for services provided under a demonstration project at a rate equal to 95 percent of Medicare payment rates. Payments will be made periodically from Medicare trust funds. Payments under this section for a demonstration project will be made periodically from Medicare trust funds, with an annual limit of $50,000,000. Payment amounts may be reduced if the Department of Veterans Affairs fails to maintain effort to avoid shifting costs onto the Medicare program. The Medicare program covers costs for hospital care and medical services for targeted Medicare-eligible veterans. Payment amounts for projects may be reduced if VA medical expenditures for targeted veterans are less than the maintenance of effort level. Maintenance of effort levels are determined based on previous fiscal year expenditures. The maintenance of effort level for VA medical expenditures for targeted veterans is adjusted based on the percentage increase or decrease in the medical care appropriation for the Department of Veterans Affairs compared to the previous fiscal year. Additionally, any decrease in VA medical expenditures for targeted veterans relative to the preceding fiscal year is also taken into account. The VA adjusts its medical care appropriations for targeted veterans based on changes in health care costs and service delivery priorities. VA medical expenditures for targeted veterans are defined as the amount spent by the Department in a fiscal year. The plan developed under Public Law 104-204 defines VA medical expenditures for targeted veterans as the amount spent by the Department of Veterans Affairs in a fiscal year for hospital care and medical services under chapter 17 of title 38, United States Code. This amount excludes expenditures for medical examinations for claims adjudication and services reimbursed under a demonstration project. The Secretaries, in consultation with the Comptroller General, closely monitor the impact on costs to the Medicare program. The Secretaries, in consultation with the Comptroller General, closely monitor the expenditures made under the medicare program for targeted medicare-eligible veterans during the demonstration project to ensure there is no increase in costs to the Medicare program. The Comptroller General audits the costs of the Secretary of Health and Human Services under the Medicare program annually and submits a report to Congress. The Comptroller General audits the costs of the Secretary of Health and Human Services under the Medicare program annually and submits a report to Congress. If expenditures increase due to a demonstration project, the Secretaries must take steps to recoup the amount and prevent future increases. The Secretaries must recoup any increase in Medicare expenditures and prevent future increases by taking specific steps, such as paying from the Department of Veterans Affairs appropriation and suspending or terminating demonstration projects. SEC. 4. EVALUATION AND REPORTS. The Secretaries will arrange for an independent entity to evaluate the health services demonstration project annually. The entity will submit a report to the Secretaries and Congress by March 1 each year, assessing the cost of care, quality compliance, and cost comparisons of participating facilities. The Secretaries will arrange for an independent evaluation of the health services demonstration project annually, assessing compliance with quality measures, cost comparisons, savings or costs to Medicare programs, changes in access to care for targeted Medicare-eligible veterans, and effects on access to care for veterans not participating in the project. A report containing recommendations on extending or expanding the project will be submitted to Congress six months after the final report. The Secretaries will submit a report to Congress within six months after the final report on whether to extend or make permanent the health services demonstration project for targeted Medicare-eligible veterans. They will also recommend expanding the project to cover more sites, increase reimbursement amounts, and consider modifying project terms if extended. Additionally, a report on establishing a new demonstration project to reimburse the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for health care services will be submitted by March 1, 1999. The Secretaries will submit a report to Congress on the feasibility of establishing a new demonstration project to reimburse the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for health care services provided to targeted Medicare-eligible veterans in managed health-care plans. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "demonstration project," "geographic service area," "Medicare program," and "Secretary." The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs and the Secretary of Health and Human Services acting jointly. A "targeted medicare-eligible veteran" is a veteran entitled to Medicare benefits with income between specified thresholds. Targeted medicare-eligible veterans are those entitled to Medicare benefits with income between specified thresholds. Their annual income falls between the applicable income threshold under section 1722(b) of title 38, United States Code, and three times that amount.
